original_data.question: A 3-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of somnolence, poor feeding, and one episode of vomiting. He is exclusively breastfed. His serum glucose concentration is 88 mg/dL and his serum ammonia concentration is 850 Î¼mol/L (N<90). Urinalysis shows an increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio. Urinary ketones are absent. This patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that catalyzes which of the following reactions?

options.A: Ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline
options.D: Glutamate and acetyl-coenzyme A to N-acetylglutamate

model_response:
The patient has a history of hyperammonemia, and the urinary orotic acid to creatinine ratio is increased. These findings are characteristic of a deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamylase, which catalyzes the reaction of ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline. This enzyme deficiency is the most common cause of hyperammonemia in the neonatal period. The accumulation of glutamate in the brain leads to somnolence. The other choices are not related to hyperammonemia.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Interruption or disruption of the intake of food/nutrition.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.
The nursing of an infant at the breast.
The act or process of concentrating, focusing the attention and mental energy on a single object to the exclusion of others.

Examination of urine by chemical, physical, or microscopic means. Routine urinalysis usually includes performing chemical screening tests, determining specific gravity, observing any unusual color or odor, screening for bacteriuria, and examining the sediment microscopically.
An intermediate product in PYRIMIDINE synthesis which plays a role in chemical conversions between DIHYDROFOLATE and TETRAHYDROFOLATE.
The determination of the ratio of total protein compared to creatinine present in a sample. The measurement may be expressed as a ratio or percentage.
Low-density crystals or stones in any part of the URINARY TRACT. Their chemical compositions often include CALCIUM OXALATE, magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite), CYSTINE, or URIC ACID.
Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Biological molecules that possess catalytic activity. They may occur naturally or be synthetically created. Enzymes are usually proteins, however CATALYTIC RNA and CATALYTIC DNA molecules have also been identified.
**Description:**Patient exhibits no reaction to the challenge agent.
